standard_metadata.standard_description: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

question.content: **Convert $7{,}348$ grams to kilograms.**   kilograms

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} ={1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1 \text{ gram} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilogram}$.
$\begin {align}{7{,}348 \text{ g}}&= {{7{,}348 \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{7{,}348 \text{ g}}&= {{7{,}348 \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{7{,}348 \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{7{,}348 \text{ g}}&= {{7{,}348 \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{7{,}348 \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{7{,}348 \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$
$7{,}348$ grams is equivalent to ${7.348}$ kilograms.

question.content: **Convert $5{,}283$ meters to kilometers.**   kilometers

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilometer} ={1{,}000}\text{ meters}$  So, $1 \text{ meter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilometers}$.
$\begin {align}{5{,}283 \text{ m}}&= {{5{,}283 \text{  m}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{5{,}283 \text{ m}}&= {{5{,}283 \text{  m}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{5{,}283 \cancel{\text{ m}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{5{,}283 \text{ m}}&= {{5{,}283 \text{  m}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{5{,}283 \cancel{\text{ m}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{5{,}283 \text{ km}}}{{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$
$5{,}283$ meters is equivalent to ${5.283}$ kilometers.

question.content: **Convert $475$ milliliters to liters.**   liters

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1 \text{ milliliter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ liter}$
$\begin {align}{475 \text{ mL}}&= {475 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{475 \text{ mL}}&= {475 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{475 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}}  \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{475 \text{ mL}}&= {475 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{475 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{475\text{ L} }{1{,}000} \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{475 \text{ mL}}&= {475 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{475 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{475\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=475\text{ L}\div1{,}000 \end{align}$

$\begin {align}{475 \text{ mL}}&= {475 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{475 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{475\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=475\text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=0.475\text{ L} \end{align}$
$475$ milliliters is equivalent to ${0.475}$ liters.

question.content: **Convert $93$ kilograms to grams.**   grams

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} ={1{,}000}\text{ grams}$
$\begin{align} 93\text{ kg} &= 93\text{ kg} \times 1{,}000\text{ g per kg}\\\\ &=93{,}000\text{ g} \end{align}$
$93$ kilograms converts to ${93{,}000}$ grams.

question.content: **Convert $45$ meters to centimeters.**   centimeters

hints.content: $1 \text{ meter} = {100}\text{ centimeters}$
$\begin{align} 45\text{ m} &= 45\text{ m} \times 100\text{ cm per m}\\\\ &=4{,}500\text{ cm} \end{align}$
$45$ meters converts to ${4{,}500}$ centimeters.

question.content: **Convert $1{,}900$ centimeters to meters.**   meters

hints.content: $1 \text{ meter} = {100}\text{ centimeters}$  So, $1 \text{ centimeter} = \dfrac{1}{100}\text{ meter}$

Let's convert ${1{,}900}$ centimeters to meters.  $\begin {align}{1{,}900 \text{ cm}}&= {{1{,}900 \text{  cm}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \text{ cm}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{1{,}900 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{1{,}900 \text{ m}}}{{100}}  \\\\ &= {1{,}900\text{ m}}\div{100}\\\\ &=19\text{ m} \end{align}$
${1{,}900}$ centimeters converts to $19$ meters.

question.content: **Convert $9.7$ liters to milliliters.**   milliliters

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$
$\begin{align} 9.7\text{ L} &= 9.7\text{ L} \times 1{,}000\text{ mL per L}\\\\ &=9{,}700\text{ mL} \end{align}$
${9.7}$ liters converts to ${9{,}700}$ milliliters.

question.content: **Arrange the following measurements in order from smallest to largest.**

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1 \text{ milliliter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ liter}$

We know $\greenD{2.1}$ liters is less than $\maroonD{3}$ liters.  But where does $\blueD{32{,}000}$ milliliters fit?  We need to convert $\blueD{32{,}000}$ milliliters to liters before we can compare.

$\begin {align}{\blueD{32{,}000} \text{ mL}}&= {\blueD{32{,}000} \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\blueD{32{,}000} \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{32{,}000}\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=\blueD{32{,}000}\text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=\blueD{32}\text{ L} \end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in liters from smallest to largest as follows:    $\greenD{2.1}$ liters   $\maroonD{3}$ liters   $\blueD{32}$ liters
So the original measurements in order from smallest to largest are as follows:    $\greenD{2.1}$ liters   $\maroonD{3}$ liters   $\blueD{32{,}000}$ milliliters

question.content: **Arrange the following measurements in order from smallest to largest.**

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1 \text{ milliliter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ liter}$

We know $\maroonD{0.7}$ liters is less than $\greenD{4.1}$ liters.  But where does $\blueD{2{,}000}$ milliliters fit?  We need to convert $\blueD{2{,}000}$ milliliters to liters before we can compare.

$\begin {align}{\blueD{2{,}000} \text{ mL}}&= {\blueD{2{,}000} \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\blueD{2{,}000} \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{2{,}000}\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=\blueD{2{,}000}\text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=\blueD{2}\text{ L} \end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in liters from smallest to largest as follows:    $\maroonD{0.7}$ liters   $\blueD{2}$ liters   $\greenD{4.1}$ liters
So the original measurements in order from smallest to largest are as follows:    $\maroonD{0.7}$ liters   $\blueD{2{,}000}$ milliliters   $\greenD{4.1}$ liters

question.content: **Arrange the following measurements in order from smallest to largest.**

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} ={1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1 \text{ gram} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilogram}$.
We know $\maroonD{15}$ grams is less than $\greenD{55}$ grams.  But where does $\blueD{0.005}$ kilograms fit?  We need to convert $\blueD{0.005}$ kilograms to grams before we can compare.
$\begin{align} \blueD{0.005}\text{ kg} &= \blueD{0.005}\text{ kg} \times 1{,}000\text{ g per kg}\\\\ &=\blueD5\text{ g} \end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in grams from smallest to largest as follows:    $\blueD{5}$ grams   $\maroonD{15}$ grams   $\greenD{55}$ grams
So the original measurements in order from smallest to largest are as follows:    $\blueD{0.005}$ kilograms   $\maroonD{15}$ grams   $\greenD{55}$ grams

question.content: **Arrange the following measurements in order from smallest to largest.**

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} ={1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1 \text{ gram} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilogram}$.
We know $\maroonD{5}$ grams is less than $\greenD{9.4}$ grams.  But where does $\blueD{0.35}$ kilograms fit?  We need to convert $\blueD{0.35}$ kilograms to grams before we can compare.
$\begin{align} \blueD{0.35}\text{ kg} &= \blueD{0.35}\text{ kg} \times 1{,}000\text{ g per kg}\\\\ &=\blueD{350}\text{ g} \end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in grams from smallest to largest as follows:    $\maroonD5$ grams   $\greenD{9.4}$ grams   $\blueD{350}$ grams
So the original measurements in order from smallest to largest are as follows:    $\maroonD5$ grams   $\greenD{9.4}$ grams   $\blueD{0.35}$ kilograms

question.content: **Which of the following measurements is greater?**

hints.content: $1 \text{ meter} = {100}\text{ centimeters}$  So, $1 \text{ centimeter} = \dfrac{1}{100}\text{ meter}$.
We need to convert $\blueD{1{,}300}$ centimeters to meters before we can compare.  $ \blueD{1{,}300}  \text{ cm}= \dfrac{\blueD{1{,}300}}{{100}}= \blueD{1{,}300}\div{100}=\blueD{13}\text{ m}$
We can order the measurements written in meters from smallest to largest as follows:    $\maroonD{5}$ meter   $\blueD{13}$ meters
$\blueD{1{,}300}$ centimeters is the greater measurement.

question.content: **Which of the following measurements is greater?**

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} ={1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1 \text{ gram} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilogram}$.

We need to convert $\blueD{4{,}500}$ grams to kilograms before we can compare.   $\begin {align}{\blueD{4{,}500} \text{ g}}&= {{\blueD{4{,}500} \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\blueD{4{,}500} \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{\blueD{4{,}500} \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {\blueD{4{,}500} \text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000} \\\\ &={\blueD{4.5}\text{ kg}}\end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in kilograms from smallest to largest as follows:    $\maroonD{0.8}$ kilogram   $\blueD{4.5}$ kilograms
$\blueD{4{,}500}$ grams is the greater measurement.

question.content: **Which of the following measurements is greater?**

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1 \text{ milliliter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ liter}$

We need to convert $\blueD{0.5}$ liters to milliliters before we can compare.  $\begin{align} \blueD{0.5}\text{ L} &= \blueD{0.5}\text{ L} \times 1{,}000\text{ mL per L}\\\\ &=\blueD{500}\text{ mL} \end{align}$
We can order the measurements written in milliliters from smallest to largest as follows:    $\maroonD{400}$ milliliters       $\blueD{500}$ milliliters
$\blueD{0.5}$ liters is the greater measurement.

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from kilometers to meters or meters to kilometers.**  Meters | Kilometers :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $13$ |   | $47$

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilometer} ={1{,}000}\text{ meters}$  So, $1 \text{ meter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilometers}$.

First, let's convert ${13}$ meters  to kilometers.  $\begin {align}{13 \text{ m}}&= {{13 \text{  m}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{13 \cancel{\text{ m}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{13 \text{ km}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {13 \text{ km}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &=0.013\text{ km} \end{align}$
Now, let's see how many meters are in ${47}$ kilometers.  $\begin{align} {47}\text{ km}&={47\text{ km}}\times{1{,}000\text{ m per km}}\\\\ &={47{,}000}\text{ m} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  Meters | Kilometers :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $13$ | $\blueD{0.013}$ $\maroonD{47{,}000}$ | $47$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from kilometers to meters or meters to kilometers.**  Meters | Kilometers :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $15{,}000$ |   | $0.86$

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilometer} ={1{,}000}\text{ meters}$  So, $1 \text{ meter} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kilometers}$.

First, let's convert ${15{,}000}$ meters to kilometers.  $\begin {align}{15{,}000 \text{ m}}&= {{15{,}000 \text{  m}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{15{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{15{,}000 \text{ km}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {15{,}000 \text{ km}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &=15\text{ km} \end{align}$
Now, let's see how many meters are in ${0.86}$ kilometers.  $\begin{align} {0.86}\text{ km}&={0.86\text{ km}}\times{1{,}000\text{ m per km}}\\\\ &={860}\text{ m} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  Meters | Kilometers :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $15{,}000$ | $\blueD{15}$ $\maroonD{860}$ | $0.86$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from centimeters to meters or meters to centimeters.**  Centimeters | Meters :-: | :-: $100$ | $1$ $170$ |   | $11$

hints.content: $1 \text{ meter} = {100}\text{ centimeters}$  So, $1 \text{ centimeter} = \dfrac{1}{100}\text{ meter}$

First, let's convert ${170}$ centimeters to meters.  $\begin {align}{170 \text{ cm}}&= {{170 \text{  cm}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \text{ cm}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{170 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{170 \text{ m}}}{{100}}  \\\\ &= {170 \text{ m}}\div{100}\\\\ &=1.7\text{ m} \end{align}$
Now, let's see how many centimeters are in  ${11}$ meters.  $\begin{align} 11\text{ m} &= 11\text{ m} \times 100\text{ cm per m}\\\\ &=1{,}100\text{ cm} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  Centimeters| Meters  :-: | :-: $100$ | $1$ $170$ | $\blueD{1.7}$ $\maroonD{1{,}100}$ | $11$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from kilograms to grams or grams to kilograms.**  Grams | Kilograms :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ | $1$  | $0.029$ $32$ |

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} = {1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1\text{ gram}= \dfrac1{{1{,}000}} \text{ kilogram}$

First, let's convert ${32}$ grams to kilograms.  $\begin {align}{32 \text{ g}}&= {{32 \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{32 \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{32 \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {32 \text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000} \\\\ &={0.032\text{ kg}}\end{align}$
Now, let's see how many grams are in ${0.029}$ kilogram.  $\begin{align} 0.029\text{ kg} &= 0.029\text{ kg} \times 1{,}000\text{ g per kg}\\\\ &=29\text{ g} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  Grams | Kilograms :-: | :-: $1000$ | $1$ $\maroonD{29}$ | $0.029$ $32$ | $\blueD{0.032}$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from kilograms to grams or grams to kilograms.**  Grams | Kilograms :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ | $1$  | $25$ $12$ |

hints.content: $1 \text{ kilogram} = {1{,}000}\text{ grams}$  So, $1\text{ gram}= \dfrac1{{1{,}000}} \text{ kilogram}$

First, let's convert ${12}$ grams to kilograms.  $\begin {align}{12 \text{ g}}&= {{12 \text{  g}}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{12 \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{12 \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {12 \text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000} \\\\ &={0.012\text{ kg}}\end{align}$
Now, let's see how many grams are in ${25}$ kilograms.  $\begin{align} 25\text{ kg} &= 25\text{ kg} \times 1{,}000\text{ g per kg}\\\\ &=25{,}000\text{ g} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  Grams | Kilograms :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ | $1$ $\maroonD{25{,}000}$ | $25$ $12$ | $\blueD{0.012}$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from milliliters to liters or liters to milliliters.**  Milliliters | Liters :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $8{,}000$ |    | $4$

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1\text{ milliliter}= \dfrac1{{1{,}000}} \text{ liter}$

First, let's convert ${8{,}000}$ milliliters to liters.  $\begin {align}{8{,}000 \text{ mL}}&= {8{,}000 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{8{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{8{,}000\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=8{,}000\text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=8\text{ L} \end{align}$
Now, let's see how many milliliters are in ${4}$ liters.  $\begin{align} 4\text{ L} &= 4\text{ L} \times 1{,}000\text{ mL per L}\\\\ &=4{,}000\text{ mL} \end{align}$

question.content: **Fill in the table to convert the units of measure from milliliters to liters or liters to milliliters.**  Milliliters | Liters :-: | :-: $1{,}000$ |  $1$ $350$ |   | $9$

hints.content: $1 \text{ liter} ={1{,}000}\text{ milliliters}$  So, $1\text{ milliliter}= \dfrac1{{1{,}000}} \text{ liter}$

First, let's convert ${350}$ milliliters to liters.  $\begin {align}{350 \text{ mL}}&= {350 \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{350 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{350\text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=350\text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=0.35\text{ L} \end{align}$
Now, let's see how many milliliters are in ${9}$ liters.  $\begin{align} 9\text{ L} &= 9\text{ L} \times 1{,}000\text{ mL per L}\\\\ &=9{,}000\text{ mL} \end{align}$
